results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 147]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film contains scenes of camping near the beach and a rail journey to Perth, in Western Australia. The trip includes a stop at ‘Rawlinna’, an Aboriginal community in Western Australia. Scenes at Rawlinna, give an indication of the relationship in society of Australian Aboriginal peoples and non-indigenous Australian people at the time.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 1940s cars travel across sand on a beach
00:00:08:00 a tea ‘billy’ on a camp fire
00:00:31:00 a large 1940s style canvas tent
00:00:55:00 overlooking the sea from clifftops
00:01:30:00 members of the Rawlinna Station Indigenous community stand for the camera and demonstrate boomerang throwing
00:02:36:00 travellers walk toward the camera
00:03:01:00 chasing a goat
00:03:04:00 playing a game of ‘two-up’
00:03:21:00 members of the Rawlinna Station Indigenous community
00:03:30:00 wandering along a constructed stone wall at a river or waterway

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 145]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows yachts sailing around a spot in (most probably) Port Phillip Bay and a school swimming competition.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:04:19:00 yachts racing
00:04:39:00 boats and yachts berthed on the sand
00:04:40:00 single person yachts on the water
00:03:03:00 indoor pool and swimmers
00:03:15:00 students assembling by the pool in readiness for swimming
00:03:18:00 swimmers in competition
00:03:58:00 relay in the pool

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel captures several rugby games in 1974 between Geelong Grammar School, Xavier College, Melbourne Grammar School and Scotch College.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 135]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows a sports or games day, involving a large group of young people, taking place in a garden outside a brick house. The footage shows a large group of people playing various games in a large garden. Some are playing golf, others are playing ‘tenniquoits’ (also known as ‘tennikoit’) where a rubber ring is thrown over a tennis-like net that separates the players. Some of the participants wear striped blazers, others wear blazers that bear a badge or crest - these may be a form of uniform or ‘club colours’ that distinguish two teams.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:55:00 a race is held, with the female-only contestants running the length of a lawn, and stooping to retrieve balls in the grass, which they put into waiting buckets
00:01:21:00 a man (standing in front of a garden hot-house or conservatory) is reading from a sheet in his hands, and appears to be directing events, as others around him move away
00:01:29:00 another race – again with contestants picking-up balls and putting them in buckets – this time includes male and females
00:01:39:00 we see four players of ‘tenniquoits’ – two each side of the net – with a game in progress as a race finishes behind them in a nearby area of the garden
00:01:48:00 a group of people (three women and three men) stand in front of a house that the garden surrounds, probably watching the golf putting that the camera soon shifts to
00:01:59:00 another ball-gathering race is run
00:02:24:00 in another race, the camera stays on a considerably older man – in a suit – running against children and youths
00:02:46:00 we see close-ups of the faces of some of the young people, as the camera moves among them
00:03:08:00 tennis players shake hands across the net
00:03:10:00 a prize-giving ceremony takes place; contestants approach a young woman and receive a small wrapped box, while others applaud in the background

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 134]
results.brief_description:

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This short film shows skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales, Australia.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:11:00 a skier falls over in spectacular style
00:02:00:00 view over one of the resort valleys, with heavy snow cover

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 133]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. The first shows downhill skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. The second, a sports day at ‘Glamorgan’ kindergarten, now the Melbourne ‘prep’ campus of Geelong Grammar.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00 skiing downhill past camera
00:01:22 skier walking cross country, building in background
00:01:29 child skiing
00:01:43 close up footage of ski lodge verandah
00:01:50 school boys lining up
00:02:03 running and wheelbarrow races on grass
00:02:54 high jump over bar on wooden blocks
00:03:13 closeup female teacher
00:03:17 bean bag race
00:03:48 running race with midway stop to put on painting smock
00:04:21 women and school girls (in hats) watch sports – hats and sunglasses
00:04:29 timekeepers desk

00:01:22 skier walking cross country, building in background
00:01:29 child skiing
00:01:43 close up footage of ski lodge verandah
00:01:50 school boys lining up
00:02:03 running and wheelbarrow races on grass
00:02:54 high jump over bar on wooden blocks
00:03:13 closeup female teacher
00:03:17 bean bag race
00:03:48 running race with midway stop to put on painting smock
00:04:21 women and school girls (in hats) watch sports – hats and sunglasses
00:04:29 timekeepers desk

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 131]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows scenes of Sydney and the Blue Mountains, NSW around 1936. There are some wonderful views of Sydney’s waterways including some houses on the lower cliffs, a few bays and a glimpse of the Harbour Bridge. Whilst in the Mountains we see walkers and horseback riding.

Later in the film there are scenes at an air terminal where one of the early Australian air services, the ‘Australian National Airways (ANA)’ is operating. The ANA was established by Charles Kingsford Smith and Charles Ulm in 1930 (ceasing in 1931).

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 family members looking out over the sea from high cliff tops
00:01:20:00, a woman is perched perilously close to the edge of the cliff whilst looking out over the view with her companions
00:02:03:00 small boats appear in the water below
00:02:17:00 family member wandering along a bush track under gums
00:02:50:00 view of the ‘Three Sisters’ at Katoomba in the Blue Mountains
00:03:14:00 member of the family on horseback
00:03:30:00 lots of handshaking and goodbyes at what we see is an air terminal, precedes an ‘Australian National Airways’ plane taking off. Children and adults wave goodbye from very close by when compared to contemporary terminals.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 130]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gadsden children of 1939 at camp, playing ball games, swimming in a river, dressing up for an impromptu pageant in the bush and playing water polo in the river.

The film then changes dramatically to scenes of the State wide bushfires which devastated many parts of regional Victoria on 13 January 1939 and known as ‘Black Friday’.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:23:00 flames in the bush, onlookers
00:01:49:00 sequence of scenes scanning the aftermath of the fires

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 122]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the family at the New South Wales coastal town of Eden, in 1938.

Opens with shots of small, masted boats in harbour (at Eden, New South Wales). One of the boats – with four men in it – is moving out of harbour under engine power.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 a pier, with vehicular rails running along it and a small two-chimneyed ship moored alongside. A small masted vessel is being prepared for launching
00:00:43:00 close-up of a man striding through the camera’s field of vision, then the camera pans slowly over the sea and coastal landscape
00:01:28:00 a bush-fringed road, with a parked car and a man sitting nearby (with back to camera). The camera lingers on the surrounding bush and hills, with the sea visible in the background. This sequence appears to be shot from a vantage point further inland than the earlier coastal scenes
00:01:57:00 two people are standing at the base of a tall building; the camera pans up the structure to show the ‘battlements’ at its top. This is ‘Boyd’s Tower’, a 23 metre structure built in 1847 by the ex-Scottish entrepreneur Ben Boyd, intended as a lighthouse, but never commissioned.
00:02:20:00 entire tower photographed from a slight distance; the full structure can be seen above the surrounding bush
00:02:37:00 same man who appeared earlier in the footage and a woman wearing riding jodhpurs are standing on a rise overlooking the water as the camera pans past them across the scene of bush and sea
00:03:06:00 same man and woman – accompanied by an older woman – are strolling through a park or garden above the coast, looking away from the camera. A dog is frolicking around them, and a horse is grazing nearby.
00:03:24:0 same man walking along a rise, looking away from the camera at the sea and headlands below him. The camera tracks him as he walks further away from it, looking back over his shoulder occasionally.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 121]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gasdsen family and friends enjoying a skiing holiday at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow
